elements.text: PART ONE
THEME
1: TV BROADCAST
MELODRAMATIC OPENING OF NEWS BROADCAST
Business, Business, Business! It’s Business Time!
INTO A TV STUDIO
Hi, I’m Chad Walker. And this is the Business News.
Business, Business, Business!
Our top story tonight.
DRAMATIC UNDERSCORING

The Drexel Corporation has put in a takeover bid for the Trans-Gal Media group. The spiralling fortunes of Augustus Scullop’s wide-ranging business behemoth have been big news in the financial pages for months now. Could his former partner’s company be the one to take it back into interplanetary dominance? We spoke to Xander Drexel at his Earth home earlier today.
CUT TO EXT. FOOTAGE, INTERVIEW

Look, no-one regrets what’s happened to Gus more than I do. Trans-Gal was a great company, we all know that. But it’s been floundering. Losing money by the bucket-load. If it’s to continue it needs a strong hand at the tiller, and with the greatest of respect, that ain’t Gus.
CUT BACK TO STUDIO
An offer was put to the company shareholders this morning and they’re expected to make a decision over the next seven days. But it would appear Augustus Scullop isn’t going down without a fight.
(CUT TO AN EXTERIOR. CHAD’S VOICE OVER CONTINUES OVER. LOTS OF
GOING UNDER AS SCULLOP AND SHEPHERD FACE THE MEDIA)
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 2
(UNDER) No comment. No comment. No, I’m not answering any questions, thank you, don’t know how I can make it any clearer. Yes, excuse me please, you, yes, you, out of the way, please, out of the way.

(OVER) Rumours abound that this weekend will see the first trial screening of Trans-Gal’s latest attempt at reigniting their fortunes. Little is known about this top secret project, but it’s said to be the brain child of highly regarded communications scientist Doctor Helen Shepherd.
(UNDER) Look I can’t say anything. No, sorry, I really can’t. It’s out of my hands. Soon as I can I’1l let you know.

She and several members of the board have joined a number of actors and crewmembers in flying to Scullop’s artificial planetoid home, ‘Transmission’, for a private viewing of the mystery television programme. If all goes well, a press launch is in the offing.
BACK IN THE STUDIO
But whatever the project is, it might be too little, too late.
(OVER THESE LAST FEW LINES FADE INTO THE BROADCAST BEING WATCHED IN SCULLOP’S OFFICE)

After all, how good can one television show be? Can Scullop arrest his company’s sliding fortunes? Or is the writing finally on the wall for one of broadcast media’s greatest ever magnates. Time will tell. I’ve been Chad Walker and this has been Business —
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 3
2: INT. SCULLOP’S OFFICE
LAST FEW LINES OF TV BROADCAST PLAYING
Off.
THE BROADCAST CUTS OUT
Too little too late. Too little too late!
It doesn’t mean anything, it’s just speculation.
Too little too late!
Of course he’s going to say that, he’s on Drexel’s channel.
I should have ruined that traitorous backstabber when I had the chance.
I don’t know why you watch it. You’ve got news programmes of your own.
Yes, but I know what we’re saying. Always good to keep an eye on the opposition...
How did they find out about the screening?
Same way they find out about everything else, presumably. Spies. Spies, spies and more spies. They’ve got eyes and ears everywhere.
Really? You’d think that’d make them easier to spot.
(BEAT) Was that an attempt at a joke, Doctor Shepherd? A witticism? Only I haven’t noticed anyone laughing.
I’m sorry.
Industrial espionage is a fact of life. They’re all jealous of me, you know. Jealous of my success.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 4
I know. So you say. All the time.
SCULLOP SIGHS
Is everything ready for the screening?
We should be ready to go within the hour. But some of the cast haven’t arrived yet...

That’s their problem. We start at my convenience, not theirs. Get it going. Let’s see them write off Augustus Scullop then. Your days are numbered, Drexel. When this show breaks you’re not going to know what’s hit you.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 5
3. INT. TARDIS CORRIDOR/STORAGE ROOM
FLIP WALKING THROUGH THE CORRIDOR
Doctor? Doctor? Where you got to? Doctor! Great, drop me in the middle of a labyrinth and then scarper, really chivalrous that is. Doctor!
(DISTANTLY WE HEAR THE SOUNDS OF A CRICKET MATCH, WITH
(MUFFLED) Oh bravo, sir! Well played.
Doctor — ?
(SHE CONTINUES DOWN THE CORRIDOR, THE SOUNDS GETTING LOUDER.
EASES OPEN A DOOR AND STEPS THROUGH. THE SOUNDS OF THE
GET LOUDER IN THE NEW ROOM, BUT REMAIN DISTORTED AS THEY’RE BEING VIEWED THROUGH THE TIME-SPACE VISUALISER)
(STILL WATCHING THE MATCH) Ha! The audacity! What a marvellous shot! [DIRECTOR’S QUESTION: BETTER CRICKET TERM TO BE HAD? ]
Er...
Good morning, Miss Jackson. Are you up?
Am I up? Course not, I’m wrapped up in bed, this is a figment of your imagination.
Excellent. Take a seat. You’re just in time for the game.
You’re not listening to me, are you? Doctor, I’ve been wandering the corridors for hours.

Have you indeed? How marvellous for you. It’s barely started. The fifth one day international cricket match between Australia and South Africa 2006. I know the result of course, but I’m not going to spoil it for you. Sit down, sit down.
Alright.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 6
SHE FLOPS DOWN BESIDE HIM
Into your cricket, are you?
Well, not as much as I was, but you never lose the taste.
Not my game, really.
You’re more of a football fan I suppose.
Oi. Class prejudice. No. Can’t be doing with none of that stuff. Bunch of idiot millionaires playing kickabout in the park, no thanks.
So what is your sport of choice?
Bowls.
Bowls?
You never watched it? It’s well addictive on a bank holiday. You catch sight of a game on BBC2, you’re gone for hours. What is this, some sort of telly? Bit over-designed, isn’t it?
Oh, it’s far more than a mere television. This is a Time-Space visualiser.
A what?
A machine that takes energy from light neutrons and converts it into electrical impulses and therefore images. With this machine we can watch any event from any period of history at any time we want.
Blimey. Black and white.
(BEAT) Is that all you can say? This is incredibly advanced technology. Centuries ahead of your time. I offer you eternity and you complain it’s not in colour?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 7

It’s not that. We’re in a time machine. We already can watch any event from any period at any time. We go there. You could do this actual match live if you wanted. Why’d you want to watch it on this manky old thing?

Well, I, er... like the commentary. And besides, what if I wanted to go again? I might end up bumping into myself and that would be terribly awkward. Some of my other iterations can be astonishingly irritating.

You don’t say. I just expected a bit more excitement travelling through time and space. We meet up again, straight away there’s Daleks and Napoleon and the battle of Waterloo. I thought day two’ll be pretty exciting to top this. Spending it watching cricket on the telly wasn’t exactly my first guess.
It is a very good game. Be fair, Flip, I wasn’t actually intending to take on a new travelling companion. I’11 show you the universe in time, but there were some things I’d been planning to do.
(BEAT) Alright then, I’1l get some popcorn from that food machine-wotsit-thing and join you.
SHE HEADS OUT
That’s the spirit. (BEAT) Oh, come now Umpire, that was clearly wide!
SOME AUDIBLE INTERFERENCE WITH THE TRANSMISSION
What the blazes? Something’s interfering with the signal... That shouldn’t happen.
HE THUMPS IT A FEW TIMES
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 8
4. INT. HOSPITALITY SUITE
GENERAL MILLING ABOUT AND SMALL TALK
Yeah, well, of course, I was offered Benedick at the Theatre of Light over in the Acteon Galaxy.
Really?
You know it? Lovely space. Had to turn it down.
Oh.
Peanuts. That’s what they were offering. Peanuts. You know what they say about them.
Er... no.
Pay peanuts, get monkeys, you hear? And Nick Kenton’s no monkey.
Well, no, quite.
So.. you got anything coming up, Matthew?
At the moment? Er, no. No, nothing really. It’s gone a bit quiet.
Really? Hadn’t noticed.
DOOR SLIDES OPEN AND CLOSED. OLIVIA ENTERS
Olivia!
Oh God.
Lovely to see you again!
Don’t touch me.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 9
(INNOCENT) What?
Matthew.
Hello. Problems getting here?
Interstellar highway was a nightmare.
You were better off on it, this place is appalling. I mean, look at it. The buffet. Worst hospitality I’ve seen. Want us to starve. I mean, take this. You ever laid eyes on a smaller sandwich?
It’s a canapé, you idiot.
A what?
SHEPHERD HAS ENTERED
Excuse me, hello, could I have your attention, please?
At last, they’re deigning to speak to us.
SILENCE
Thank you for your patience, we’re getting the machine warmed up, we'll be able to begin the screening in a couple of minutes. Sorry about the wait. We’ll keep you informed.
SHE EXITS
Fantastic.
It’s a complicated process, there’s bound to be teething problems, that’s the point of doing this pre-launch.
What? I suppose. Bit of a fox though isn’t she, that Doctor Shepherd, eh, Matthew? Bit of a looker?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 10
I, er... wouldn’t know.
Not your type, eh? Never mind, more for me. Wouldn’t mind getting televisual with her.
What does that even mean?
PAUSE
Still. There’s plenty of free booze over there. Shame to waste it. Who wants some wine?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 11
5. INT. TARDIS CORRIDOR/CONSOLE ROOM
BEEPS OF THE FOOD MACHINE DEPOSITING TWO BAGS
Great. Two bags, fantastic.
THE DOCTOR IS BUSTLING DOWN THE CORRIDOR
Oh, there you are. I’ve got salted, I’ve got toffee. No sweet though, cos that’s rank. Hey, where you going?
SHE FOLLOWS HIM
The console room. We don’t have time for popcorn I’m afraid.
What? But I made it and everything.
Something’s interfering with the picture on the visualiser. All the sound you like but no images. That shouldn’t happen.
Well, calm down, adjust the aerial.
It’s rather more complicated than that.
(THEY WALK INTO THE CONTROL ROOM. FLIP STARTS TO EAT THR POPCORN. THE DOCTOR MANIPULATES THE CONTROLS )
That machine doesn’t work like a conventional television. Something’s interfering with reality itself. Warping it.
That don’t sound good.
Something of an understatement. The effects are potentially devastating.
So what we doing about it?
I’m trying to locate the source of the trouble. (A BEEP) There. The planet... Transmission.
Guessing that’s not its real name.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 12
Not a real planet if these readings are to be believed. It’s artificial.
What, like the Death Star?

‘Death’... ? Er... Hopefully nothing so ominous. It isn’t necessarily a major problem, not with the right level of technology. Nonetheless we should probably stop by and ensure they know what they’re doing.
So. Cricket’s off then. You know, I’m oddly disappointed.
That’s the beauty of the Visualiser. There’s always another day for cricket.
HE STARTS THE MATERIALISATION PROCESS
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 13
6. INT. SCREENING ROOM
A CROWD FILING IN
Yes, if you could take your seats quickly please. We don’t have all day.
(MUTTERED) Could have fooled me.
What?
Nothing, nothing.
EVERYONE BEGINS TO SETTLE
Is that everyone? Good...
Er, not quite, the Porcians don’t seem to have arrived yet.
Then they should have left earlier, shouldn’t they? Not my problem.
I was just... saying...
Welcome, welcome, good day to you all. Thank you for coming. It’s greatly appreciated.
(COUGHING THE PHRASE) Get on with it.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 14

(BEAT. IGNORING HIM) Yes, as you may know I’ve not had the best time recently. Some unsuccessful commissions, an unco- operative ex-wife. With a rather sizeable alimony settlement. Extortionate in fact. Probably seduced the judge like all the rest of her flings, the witch. And, of course, the most heinous of betrayals by my former business partner, may he rot in hell. There were days when I thought about closing down Trans-Gal media. Closing it down and living a quiet life. But thanks to the valiant effort of Doctor Shepherd, and your sterling work over the last few months, I believe those days have passed. I can see the light at the end of the tunnel. And that light is my new show. Ladies and gentlemen, without further ado, I give you the very first episode of my new TV programme. ‘Laser’.
About time too.
(INTO COMMUNICATOR) Control room?
(OVER COMMUNICATOR) Sir?
You may start.
THE BUZZ OF MACHINERY STARTING
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 15
7. INT. TARDIS CONSOLE ROOM
THE TARDIS IS PROPERLY MATERIALISING NOW
Here we are. Coming in to land and...
(THERE’S A JOLT. SUDDENLY THE MATERIALISATION SOUNDS WRONG.
SOUND. THE TARDIS GROANS. )
No!
What is it? This don’t sound right!
Whatever’s causing the effect’s been magnified. It’s twisting local space-time. Phasing it in and out.
It’s got worse you mean?

More than that. It’s doing what we’re doing! We’re squeezing through the gaps in reality at precisely the same moment it’s pulling them apart. Multiple unstable dimensional fields can’t operate in the same location. The component atoms could end up merged or dispersed or even destroyed!
And I presume we’re the component atoms. I thought you said this needn’t be a problem?
Not if I can bring the TARDIS back in sync with the timelines. I have to abort the materialisation, land close by but outside of the warp field, otherwise —
SUDDEN WARPING SOUND
(FADING AWAY) Doctor! Doctor... I feel... weird...
What? No! Flip! You’re fading out —
(FADING FURTHER) What’s happening to me! Doctor, can’t you stop it? I don’t —
SHE’S GONE, AS IS THE WARPING. ALARMS ARE SILENT.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 16
She’s gone. One morning in and she’s vanished already, that’s a record even for me.
AN EXPLOSION OF SPARKS
First things first. I’ll find a way to get her back later...
HE STRUGGLES WITH DIALS DESPERATELY
Now!
THE SOUND OF THE TARDIS STARTING TO MATERIALISE
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 17
8. INT. SCREENING ROOM
(MACHINERY AS BEFORE, WITH SMALL BANGS AND FLASHES. MINOR PANIC FROM THE CROWD. SHEPHERD OVER COMMUNICATOR. )
What’s happening! I thought you said this thing was ready!
(D) It was, it is, there’s interference in the reality matrix...
There'll be interference in your employment contract if you don’t get it sorted out.
(D) I’m trying... There!
(THE MACHINERY POWERS DOWN. THE BANGS AND FLASHES STOP, THE
SUBSIDES. )
That doesn’t appear to have fixed it. If I didn’t know better I’d think you’d switched it off.
(D) I have to examine the systems, find out what the problem is. I can’t do that while it’s running.
More delays?
(D) Do you want it to work or don’t you?
PAUSE
(OUT LOUD) Ladies and Gentlemen, apologies. It appears my praise for Doctor Shepherd was a trifle premature. We’1ll have to delay the premiere a little while longer.
Oh, good grief...
If you would kindly return to the hospitality suite, we’ll let you know when things are ready. (BEAT) All right then, go. Get on with it, get out.
THE CROWD START TO FILE OUT
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 18
(INTO COMMUNICATOR) This better not happen twice, Doctor
Shepherd. I’m relying on you. I’ve invested a lot of money in this machine of yours. If it can’t do what you say —
(D) Tt-can.- it wall.
It better. Get a move on.
HE EXITS
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 19
9. INT. TARDIS CONSOLE ROOM
(EXT. SOUND: THE TARDIS MATERIALISES FULLY IN AN ECHOEY
BAY. THEN INSIDE THE CONSOLE ROOM)
Excellent. Bit off the original target, but near enough. Now... to fand:..
(DISTANT, DISTORTED) Doctor! Doctor!
Flip?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 20
10. INT. TARDIS STORAGE ROOM
THE VISUALISER STILL BUZZING. FLIP SPEAKING THROUGH IT
(DISTORT) Doctor? Doctor are you there? I don’t know where I am, please...
THE DOOR OPENS
Now that is odd.
(D) What? That is well weird, it's like your voice is everywhere. Doctor, is that you?
Yes.
(D) Oh thank goodness, I was so worried. I’m on some weird alien planet.
You can hear me?
(D) Yeah.
How? In your head?
(D) No... you're just sort of... all around me, like. What is it, some TARDIS gubbins like that translator thingy?
Not exactly. We’re speaking through the visualiser.
(D) What? How does that work?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 21
11. EXT. BARREN SURFACE (CONTINUOUS
FLIP IS ON A BARREN WORLD. WIND HOWLING. COLD AMBIENCE
(DISTORT) I’ve no idea. Usually you input a specific location. It seems to have found you all by itself. I mean, I’m glad you’re safe, but... that is strange...
Well, don’t look a gift horse in the mouth, eh? Where am I?
(D) I don’t know. I can’t see you, it’s only your voice coming through. Whatever the anomaly was that was interfering with the picture, it’s obviously ongoing.
Well, surely you know what’s happened to me? Where I went?
(D) You were pulled into the vortex. You could be anywhere, and in any time. The past, the future. There’s no way of telling.
Oh, fantastic. I’m stuck here, am I, I’m lost? Great. See the universe he says, all time and space he says, so glad I took you up on that offer.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 22
12. INT. TARDIS STORAGE ROOM (CONTINUOUS

Don’t panic. There are ways and means. Tell me. Where you are, what does it look like? If there’s any unusual flora or fauna or if the environment’s especially idiosyncratic it might help me to identify your location.
(DISTORTED) Looks like.. looks like a quarry.
PAUSE
Yes, that doesn’t exactly narrow it down.
(DISTORTED) You are useless.
Now, now, I’m sure there’s a way around this.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 23
13. EXT. BARREN SURFACE (CONTINUOUS
(DISTORTED) Look, I’ve landed on the surface of Transmission, maybe if I can track down the source of the interference it’1ll give me a clue as to where it deflected you.
I’m not totally convinced by any plan that hinges on the word ‘maybe’.
(D) Well, I’m clutching at straws and it’s the best chance we've got. I’1l reconnoitre our surroundings and keep you informed of anything I find. We can’t lose this connection, so don’t go anywhere.
I’m on a barren alien planet, Doctor, where’m I gonna go, Tescos?
IS SHE SPEAKING INTO???
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 24
14. INT. TARDIS STORAGE ROOM (CONTINUOUS
It might sound a stupid instruction, but you’d be astounded how many of my former companions were predisposed to ambulation.
(DISTORT) You mean ‘had a tendency to walk about’?
Yes.
(D) Well then why didn’t you say that?
Don’t worry Flip. I’ll find you. Somehow or other.
HE EXITS THE STORAGE ROOM
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 25
15. EXT. BARREN SURFACE
Yeah, you do that. Any time you want. (BEAT) Least I’ve got my popcorn.
(SHE STARTS TO EAT. A SCREAM NEARBY. A GROUP OF MONSTERS GROWLING)
Oh, now don’t. Not right away. He’s told me to wait, I’m going to wait. Don’t send me monsters now!
(DISTANT) Help me! Help me, please!
MORE SCREAMS
Oh, for the love of — Oh, how hard can this particular bit of quarry be to find again? Right, that’s it. Sorry Doctor. Here
I go! (CALLING OUT) Oi! Don’t worry! I’m coming!
SHE RUNS OFF. THE SCREAMING CONTINUES
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 26
16. INT. DOCKING BAY
THE TARDIS DOOR OPENS
Hmm. A docking bay... Let’s see where that interference is coming from... Tracker... on.
(HE SWITCHES ON A DEVICE. IT BEEPS A FEW TIMES.
CHIMBLY AND HIS FELLOW PORCIANS —ABOUT TEN — ARE APPROACHING, OINKING. DISTANT AT FIRST)
That is the last time I let you give directions.
Sorry, Sir.
(SWITCHING OFF MACHINE) Better not be seen. Not before I know what’s going on.
THE TARDIS DOOR SHUTS. THE PORCIANS GET CLOSER AND PASS
We should have been here yesterday. If you hadn’t suggested that left turn at Delta Magna...
I thought it was a short cut.
A short cut? It doubled the journey time. Why couldn’t you use Star-Nav? I do not tolerate failure, you know that. I’ve told you often enough.
Yes sir.
If the plan goes wrong because of you I won’t be responsible for my actions. This way men.
THEY’VE GONE. THE TARDIS DOOR OPENS
Porcians?!? What are those pigs doing here? I should — No. No, first things first. Rescue Flip. Then deal with them. So. The
source of the interference...
HE SWITCHES ON HIS MACHINE
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 27
17. EXT. BARREN SURFACE
(JANCEY UNDER ATTACK FROM GROWLING WARMONGERS. SHE’S SCREAMING LOTS)
Help! Help, please someone, help!
FLIP RUNS UP
Blimey. Space wart-—hogs?
JANCEY SCREAMS
Hey, leave her alone, pick on someone your own size! Actually, that would probably have been better if she wasn’t taller than you. You really are quite titchy, aren’t you?
Slobatuna dancrala liblon!
(BEAT) Sorry, what?
Help! It’s the Warmongers! They’re trying to kill me!
SCREAMS
The Warmongers? That’s these guys?
Cabalon tarilba!
Yeah, don’t understand what you’re saying, mate, I — hold on. Why don’t I understand what you’re saying?
Pentistananta! Raklasha!
SEVERAL LASERS CHARGE
Oh great, pigs with guns.
They’re going to shoot us! (SCREAMS)
D’you think? (BEAT) Oi, Porkchop!
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 28
IT GRUNTS AT HER
Like popcorn? Chew on this!
SHE FLINGS HER POPCORN AT THE MONSTERS
Leg it!
THE WARMONGERS SCRAMBLE FOR THE POPCORN. JANCEY AND FLIP RUN
How'd you know that’d distract them?
They’re pigs aren’t they? Eat anything. Seemed like a good idea...
It was.
BLASTS FROM BEHIND, CONTINUING IRREGULARLY UNDER
They’re pursuing us. Quick! We have to get to your spaceship!
My what?
Your spaceship. You must have landed close by.
I don’t have a spaceship. Well, not one I can get to.
(BEAT) Then we must get to your teleport station!
Er, no, not got one of them either.
(BEAT) Hypercar?
Nope.
Travel bracelet?
sorry.
Trans-dimensional wormhole gate?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 29
Not last time I checked.
What do you have?
Pair of feet and some trainers?
That’s it? That’s your plan? Keep running and hope they don’t catch us?
Yep.
Wonderful.

I’m sorry! You were screaming, I came to help. That’s as far as I got. Quick, over this hill. (SHE SCRAMBLES UP) Look, there’s some caves over there. Maybe we can — jeez. There’s, like, bodies everywhere.
Endless death. The terrifying legacy of Lord Krarn.
Who? Look, what happened here? What is this place?
You don’t know? This is Earth. You’re in England.
Eh?
It’s been like this for five years. Since the day it happened.
Since... since what happened?
A SUDDEN BLAST — TOO CLOSE
Hold that thought. No time now. Those caves. Quick as you can!
THEY RUN OFF
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 30
18. CONTROL ROOM
SHEPHERD INTO COMMUNICATOR, SCULLOP’S VOICE COMING FROM IT
(DISTORT) You’re ready? What was the matter?
I don’t know. Whatever got caught in the field vanished as quickly as it arrived, I can’t find the slightest trace of it anymore.
(D) But you don’t know what happened? Where it came from, what it was?
I’m afraid not.
(D) Then it might still be a problem.
I don’t think so.
(D) It might still disrupt the screening.
The systems are fine. There’s a slight anomaly in the recording, but that’1ll clear itself up, I’m sure.
(D) Are you? Are you really?
Yes.
(D) Then we shall proceed. But remember. You embarrass me
further and I can find another scientist, you understand? Scullop out.
THE COMMUNICATOR CUTS OUT
Yes sir.
SHE OPERATES THE MACHINERY. IT STARTS TO WARM UP
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 31
19. INT. HOSPITALITY SUITE
NICK SPEAKING INTO A PHONE
Yeah, can I speak to Jean, please? / It’s Nick, Nick Kenton. / Well, what do you mean she’s out of the office?
You know the more I hear that man, the more I’m amazed I was prepared to let him kiss me. No job pays that much.
(INTO PHONE) Then find her, get her to call me back...
Better hope we don’t go to series, then.
A DOOR SLIDES OPEN. THE PORCIANS ENTER
Bow down, humans. We have arrived.
Oh, hello.
Afternoon.
(CLOSING PHONE) And look who’s decided to be fashionably late. Wanted to snatch the publicity did you?
Er. Yes. Yes that’s it. That’s precisely the reason we delayed. Honest.
Don’t worry, you’ve not missed anything, there’s been... technical issues...
Really?
Delays, delays, delays. All we’ve had. Just been hanging around. It’s pathetic. What’s taking them so long?
Got somewhere you need to be going, have you?
What? No. It’s just...
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 32
SCULLOP ENTERS
Ladies and Gentlemen. I have received word from Doctor
Shepherd. If you would like to proceed to the screening room we will start the screening again. Only this time with no unfortunate errors.
At last...
THEY FILE OUT
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 33
20. INT. CAVE
DANK. WATER DRIPS
Great. They’re passing. They won’t spot us in here.
They’1l come back. They always come back.
What are they?

(QUICK, ALMOST ROTE) The Warmongers. Brutal pig aliens, servants of the evil and indestructable Lord Krarn. Five years ago they invaded Earth at his command. No-one knows for sure how they did it, but it seems a human traitor helped open up a hyperspace tunnel from their homeworld. They appeared suddenly one day in all the major cities and wiped out the heads of government. Krarn installed himself as dictator of Earth and has been wiping out all the towns and cities that oppose him, killing everyone in them and levelling them to the ground. This is his latest conquest.
(BEAT) Right. Well that was comprehensive, thanks. So that barren wilderness out there used to be a town?
Yes.
Which one?
Stevenage.
Hmm. Well, it’s not changed that much. (PAUSE) They’re coming round again. Get further back, keep quiet. Don’t want them to hear us.
They’1l find us. They’1ll find us and kill us.
No they won’t. Not if we don’t draw their attention...
We’re dead. I tell you we’re dead! (SHE STARTS SCREAMING)

elements.text: PART TWO
THEME
24. SCREENING ROOM (CONTINUED)
Who’s that girl? You cast a new love interest in this without telling me? That’s outrageous. Who is she?
I’ve no idea! I really don’t. I haven’t the faintest notion who that is!
(ENTERING) That is Philippa Jackson. Otherwise known as Flip.
Who in — ? Guards! We’ve an intruder!
No, wait, listen to me! That’s my friend. Don’t you see? Somehow or other she’s got herself trapped inside your television programme!
What?
Um... what’s going on?
(PRESSES BUTTON ON COMMUNICATOR) Doctor Shepherd? Are you there? Doctor Shepherd! (BEAT) Where are you!
(ENTERING) Right here.
She was good enough to show me the way.
Have we stopped?
You know this man?
I’ve only just met him. Calls himself the Doctor.
Are we going on?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 42
Can we leave the cross-examination for the moment, it’s imperative I get my friend out of there!
Who is he?
Not a clue. But he does seem to know what he’s talking about.
Please, you must see there’s a problem with your production!
There’s nothing wrong with it.
Perhaps not before, but there certainly is now. And I’m the only person that can repair it.
I did say there was an anomaly in the recording, it could be this gentleman’s friend.
Thank you.
PAUSE
Meet me in my office. This is not the place for a discussion. Doctor Shepherd, show him the way. You’re apparently good at that.
Follow me.
Lead on.
THEY EXIT

I’m sorry for the commotion, ladies and gentlemen. We seem to have a foreign body infecting our piece. Rest assured all possible steps are being taken to rectify the situation. If you'll just wait here...
SCULLOP EXITS
This day gets better and better...
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 43
GENERAL MILLING
(MUTTERED) Doctor, sir! She called him Doctor!
(MUTTERED) I know. I don’t like the sound of this. If the Doctor’s here he could interfere with our plans. Follow them. Discretely. Find out what he knows.
Yes, sir. (MAKES TO GO)
No, not so fast, I haven’t finished yet.
Oh, sorry, I thought —

Find out what he knows. If he does intend to make a nuisance of himself... we may have to leave his scenes on the cutting room floor. For the rest of his life! (EVIL LAUGH. PAUSE) Alright, that’s it, I’m done, you can go now.
Thank you sir.
(JUNIOR EXITS. THE PROGRAMME HAS BEEN RUNNING ON WITH AMBIENT
SINCE THE CLIFFHANGER, BUT NOW IT REJOINS FLIP, JANCEY AND LASER)
Jeez, bit of a walk, isn’t it? Thank goodness it’s Stevenage and not Edinburgh, don’t think I could stand all those hills...
Oh, hello. Looks like we’ve caught up with the action again...
Wow. Is that really what I look like? I — am — gorgeous. Best- looking thing in this show.
Thanks.
What? Oh, you’re tolerable Liv, don’t get me wrong. But look at those cheek-bones. Camera loves me. Loves me.
Oh, good grief.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 44
25. EXT. BARREN SURFACE
FLIP AND CO. MARCHING ALONG
Where we heading for, your spaceship?
It’s parked over there.
Wow. Turbo-temporal-fusion engines and a dymetrecite hull! It’s one of the most advanced ships I’ve ever seen!
Course. Earth corps don’t skimp on expenses. Not when lives are at stake.
But... turbo-temporal-fusion? Dymetrecite?
Yes?
That’s nonsense isn’t it? Gobbledegook. I’m no Stephen Hawkings, but I’ve seen Star Trek and I know technobabble when I hear it.
I don’t pretend to understand the science myself, all I know is it works.
Yeah, but —
Thank you for rescuing us, Mister Laser. Who knows what we'd have done without you.
That’s quite alright. It’s my job. When we get to the ship I’1l signal home command. Get a transporter, take you two out of danger. (BEAT) Oh, but where are my manners, I don’t even know your names!
Jancey, I’m called Jancey.
Jancey? Lovely name. Lovely name for a lovely woman.
JANCEY GIGGLES
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 45
And you? What do they call you young lady?
They don’t call me young lady for a start.
Ha! You’re a perky one, aren’t you?
(BEAT) My name’s Phillipa. But they call me Flip.
Good to meet you, Flip. I was impressed by your bravery at the
cave. Few are prepared to face down the Warmongers without a weapon.
Oh. Well, it’s just what I do, really.
Don’t undersell yourself. It’s a rare quality. Be proud of it.
Er.. okay. Cheers.
I was quite brave too.
.yeeeess. Here we are.
(THEY'VE REACHED HIS SPACESHIP. HE PRESSES A SWITCH. A RAMP
OPEN)
Home sweet home. Welcome aboard.
THEY CLAMBER UP THE RAMP
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 46
26. INT. LASER’S SHIP ENTRANCEWAY (CONTINUOUS
LASER WALKS INTO THE SHIP, FLIP AND JANCEY FOLLOWING
If you’ll make your way to the Space-Lounge, I can —
SEVERAL GUNS ARE RACKED AROUND THEM. A DRAMATIC CHORD
What is it with the music?
Mister Laser.
Krarn. I might have known. I thought I detected a certain stench in the air.
Did you? Well, let me assure you that soon the only stench you'll be smelling will be the one emanating from your putrefying corpses.
No!
That doesn’t work.
What?
How’ll we be able to smell our putrefying corpses if we’re dead?
(BEAT) Um...
How did you get past the security lock?
It appears not everyone in Earth Corps is entirely on your Side. They provided me with a universal code-breaker.
It was a trap?
A trap I have now sprung.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 47
No! We’re all going to die!
JANCEY SCREAMS
Not again...
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 48
27. INT. SCULLOP’S OFFICE
You’re telling me everything happening to Flip is actually occurring now? That it exists for her in reality?
That world, its people. They’re simultaneously fictional and real.
So if she’s wounded in any way —
The wound’s as genuine as any incurred in her ordinary existence.
That’s taking verisimilitude to a whole new level.
We call the process ‘Reel-Life’. R, double-e, 1. Neat little pun.
You’11 forgive me if I don’t applaud your linguistic mastery quite yet.
The reality generator creates a dimensional bubble containing the world of the programme, a world derived from the recorded performances of the actors.
And this bubble is overlaid onto our dimension at the place of screening, both dimensions co-existing at the same point in space-time?
I know it’s a difficult concept to grasp —
Not at all, it’s dimensional transcendentalism. My people have been utilising that exact science for centuries. Albeit for purposes a little more advanced than mere entertainment.
Don’t knock mere entertainment, Doctor. For some people it’s all they have.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 49
No wonder it interfered with the TARDIS’ arrival. It’s hard enough maintaining the simultaneous stability of two secured dimensional fields, four is asking for trouble.
TARDIS?

My... Ship. We must have passed through your bubble during materialisation. The different realities intermingled for a split second and Flip was snatched away by the fictional universe. We’re lucky it was only her.
We are?
If I’d been lost as well we’d have very little hope of unravelling this mess. As it is, we might just have a chance. (BEAT) Can we not simply stop the screening? Get her out of harm’s way?
It wouldn’t work. The dimensional bubble maintains a separate existence. Usually the characters follow a pre-programmed path
They stick to the script, in other words?

Precisely. But they don’t stop being there the moment the story moves away or you stop transmitting. They’re still alive. They move into a sort of holding pattern. Maintaining a physical reality but not doing anything that impacts upon the plot.
Even without recorded material?

We don’t need a script in reality, why should they? They’re alive. That’s the problem. Their ability to exist independently of the narrative means that if a new factor’s introduced, like your friend —
- then they start to improvise, for want of a better term.
We’ve no means of telling where the story’s going.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 50
If only I could talk to her!
But you did before, you said.

I could reach her through the visualiser because that machine and yours are based on the same technology, that’s why the transmission interfered with my signal. But now she’s moved from the reception field she’1ll be impossible to track down.
So, what’s the plan?
I think I should take a closer look at this machine of yours. If I can understand precisely what happened there’s every chance I can reverse the process.
A closer look?
Is that a problem?
This isn’t some elaborate ruse is it?
Ruse? To what end?
Mister Scullop is a little paranoid about spies.
Your machine is a unique creation, Doctor Shepherd, worth a fortune to my competitors, I think some prudence is appropriate under the circumstances.
I can assure you my only interest is in the wellbeing of my
friend.
Very well. Follow me.
HE OPENS THE DOOR. JUNIOR IS OUTSIDE
Um... er.. hello. Is this not the toilets?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 51
No.
Oh. Sorry. Must have got lost...
HE RUNS OFF
Was he listening in?
Apparently so. Perhaps Mister Scullop’s fears of espionage aren’t quite so unfounded as one might think.
It’s an actor. Him and the rest of his species played the monsters in the show. He picked the wrong door or something. Nothing to be worried about.

On the contrary, that is a Porcian and they’re very, very dangerous indeed. Worrying about them should be high on everyone’s agenda. But for the moment, we have more pressing priorities. The reality generator, come along.
THEY LEAVE
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 52
28. INT. LASER’S SHIP ANTEROOM
THE WARMONGERS BABBLING INCOMPREHENSIBLY
Rob la shumbla/Ploypli schlumblom.
You know, I still can’t understand a word they’re saying.
Universal translators don’t work with the Warmongers. No linguists survive long enough to make a detailed study of the language.
But the way the Doctor said it, it’s automatic. The TARDIS reads their minds, figures out what they’re saying, that’s what I hear. Should be able to understand them.
Doctor? TARDIS?
Now you’re just making up words.

Yeah, well, it’s a bit hard to explain. With any luck he’1l be along soon and I won’t have to bother. Sort this lot out. (BEAT) Why’s this Krarn bloke not killed us anyway? Why lock us up, not shoot us?
That ulcerous monstrosity must have some other nefarious scheme in mind.
I hear he likes to make his victims suffer. He is a truly evil man.

Or he’s rubbish at his job. He’s like every Bond villain you’ve ever seen. All walking away from elaborate death traps, then acting all surprised when the hero turns up with a harpoon gun and a punchline.
You intrigue me, Flip. You appear so innocent and yet talk of many dark things. Who are these Bond villains of which you speak? Did they hurt you?
You are weird, you know that?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 53
THE DOOR OPENS. KRARN ENTERS
I trust my subordinates have been keeping you... entertained.
Yeah, they’ve broken out the Jenga, Twister, it’s been like Christmas at me nan’s.
yes. I thought you would like to know, Mister Laser, that your plans have failed. Soon the Earth will be mine.
You fiend.
It need not have been this way. Had you not killed my wife I would not have made the universe feel my vengeance.
(TO LASER) You did what?
It’s not as it sounds. It was... an accident.
You could have saved her.
Only at the expense of thousands of other lives!
What exactly happened?
PAUSE
Um...
EY...
SILENCE
It’s not important right now. All that matters is you know I
am one step closer to my ultimate victory.
What do you want, you monster?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 54
Isn’t it obvious? To take over the universe. (EVIL LAUGH)
Why?
(BEAT) What?
Why'd you want to do that? It’d be a proper huge job looking after it, think of the admin.

I mean, the universe is like well vast. More trouble than it’s worth. Actually, I reckon when you say universe you mean galaxy, that’d make more sense, lots of people get them confused. Even then it’d be hard work.
It seems to me that you are hard work.
And how does killing everyone on Earth help you towards that anyway? I can’t make out how it’s a logical step in the process.
Everyone must die at my hands.
Yeah, but why? You must have a reason.
Because... because... Oh, shut up! (PAUSE) The universe will know my pain. My only regret is that you, Jack Laser, will not be there to see it.
HE EXITS
This gets stranger all the time.
CROSS FADE TO —
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 55
29. INT. SCREENING ROOM
(THE TAIL END OF THE PREVIOUS SCENE CONTINUES IN THE SCREENING ROOM, SLIGHTLY DISTORTED)
Why’d he even come in here? Just ranted a bit and then went out again.
He likes to gloat.
But still. People need a reason to do stuff. What did he gain? Something deeply odd’s going on here.
You know, you can be quite scary when you try, Matthew.
Oh, um. thanks. Just said the lines. All in the script. Though that wasn’t exactly... me.. there. Now. As such.
Really? Yeah, I don’t remember filming that either. Must have had a rough night.
You have no idea how this process works, do you?
I’m not paid to understand the kit, love. That’s the techies’ job. They’re the ones who like playing with fairy lights, not me.
Never did work out that back story precisely, did we? The wife’s death thing.
Told you, he’s saving that for the series. Don’t want to play something different in the pilot, it’d get confusing.
Yes, but.. you know... felt a bit... unprofessional.
THE DOOR OPENS. JUNIOR RUNS IN
Sir, sir!
Ah, you're back. What have you learnt?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney
pretty much nothing sir.
(BEAT) Remind me what I pay you for?
It’s not my fault. I was discovered.
Discovered?
The Doctor seemed very interested in the to look at it. I couldn’t get out of the
The machine, eh? Perhaps he is after the We may have to accelerate our plans.
Page 56
machine. He was going way quickly enough.
same thing as we are.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 57
30. INT. CONTROL ROOM
THE DOCTOR EXAMINING THE DEVICE
Do be careful with that, it’s incredibly valuable.
So’s Phillipa. Doctor Shepherd?
Yes?
This machine of yours. It isn’t technically yours at all, is piers
PAUSE
What’s he talking about?
I’ve no idea.
Come now. This creation outstrips humanity’s current level of advancement by centuries if not millennia. Either you’re an unbelievably gifted scientific genius or this is of alien manufacture.
PAUSE
Doctor Shepherd?
(BEAT) I bought it fair and square.
Aha! I knew it!
This is old technology? I’m paying a large portion of my Significantly diminished fortune for something that already exists?
Not used for this precise application, no.

FLIP: I mean, the universe is like well vast. More trouble than it’s worth. Actually, I reckon when you say universe you mean galaxy, that’d make more sense, lots of people get them confused. Even then it’d be hard work.
KRARN: It seems to me that you are hard work.
FLIP: And how does killing everyone on Earth help you towards that anyway? I can’t make out how it’s a logical step in the process.
KRARN: Everyone must die at my hands.
FLIP: Yeah, but why? You must have a reason.
KRARN: Because... because... Oh, shut up! (PAUSE) The universe will know my pain. My only regret is that you, Jack Laser, will not be there to see it.
FLIP: This gets stranger all the time.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 55
DOCTOR WHO: (THE TAIL END OF THE PREVIOUS SCENE CONTINUES IN THE SCREENING ROOM, SLIGHTLY DISTORTED)
FLIP: Why’d he even come in here? Just ranted a bit and then went out again.
LASER: He likes to gloat.
FLIP: But still. People need a reason to do stuff. What did he gain? Something deeply odd’s going on here.
NICK: You know, you can be quite scary when you try, Matthew.
MATTHEW: Oh, um. thanks. Just said the lines. All in the script. Though that wasn’t exactly... me.. there. Now. As such.
NICK: Really? Yeah, I don’t remember filming that either. Must have had a rough night.
OLIVIA: You have no idea how this process works, do you?
NICK: I’m not paid to understand the kit, love. That’s the techies’ job. They’re the ones who like playing with fairy lights, not me.
MATTHEW: Never did work out that back story precisely, did we? The wife’s death thing.
NICK: Told you, he’s saving that for the series. Don’t want to play something different in the pilot, it’d get confusing.
MATTHEW: Yes, but.. you know... felt a bit... unprofessional.
JUNIOR: Sir, sir!
CHIMBLY: Ah, you're back. What have you learnt?
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney
JUNIOR: pretty much nothing sir.
CHIMBLY: (BEAT) Remind me what I pay you for?
JUNIOR: It’s not my fault. I was discovered.
CHIMBLY: Discovered?
JUNIOR: The Doctor seemed very interested in the to look at it. I couldn’t get out of the
CHIMBLY: The machine, eh? Perhaps he is after the We may have to accelerate our plans.
CHIMBLY: Page 56
CHIMBLY: machine. He was going way quickly enough.
CHIMBLY: same thing as we are.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 57
SCULLOP: Do be careful with that, it’s incredibly valuable.
DOCTOR: So’s Phillipa. Doctor Shepherd?
SHEPHERD: Yes?
DOCTOR: This machine of yours. It isn’t technically yours at all, is piers
SCULLOP: What’s he talking about?
SHEPHERD: I’ve no idea.
DOCTOR: Come now. This creation outstrips humanity’s current level of advancement by centuries if not millennia. Either you’re an unbelievably gifted scientific genius or this is of alien manufacture.
SCULLOP: Doctor Shepherd?
SHEPHERD: (BEAT) I bought it fair and square.
DOCTOR: Aha! I knew it!
SCULLOP: This is old technology? I’m paying a large portion of my Significantly diminished fortune for something that already exists?
SHEPHERD: Not used for this precise application, no.
SCULLOP: That hardly matters! My copyright’s worthless! Anyone could duplicate this! Drexel could duplicate this!
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 58
SHEPHERD: I think you’re underestimating the input I’ve had into its development —
SCULLOP: Am I? Rest assured, Doctor Shepherd, that when this crisis is over, I shall be going over the small print of your contract in microscopic detail.
SHEPHERD: Yes, Mister Scullop.
DOCTOR: Where precisely is it from?
SHEPHERD: (BEAT) It’s Dashran.
DOCTOR: Ah! The legendary Dream-Spinners of Dashrah, yes, you know I’ve always wondered what happened to them. Even tried to find out once...
SCULLOP: Who?
DOCTOR: A great lost race of the ninth galaxy. Long dead. They were able to warp reality itself to their very will, alter the physical realities of space-time through detailed computation and mathematical processes. You know, that makes this machine incredibly dangerous.
SHEPHERD: How so?
DOCTOR: A machine that can outwit the scientific laws of our universe? How can it not? Whatever fiction this machine creates, it becomes real. No matter how nonsensical, no matter how outlandish. It can rewrite reality, history, all time and Space as we know it!
SHEPHERD: But only within the bubble dimension.
DOCTOR: A dimension you’ve overlaid onto ours! Any interaction of the two could lead to total disaster!
SHEPHERD: Hence the security protocols.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 59
DOCTOR: The what?
SHEPHERD: I’m not as stupid as you think. This circuit here keeps the dimensions ‘separate’ in time. The bubble’s a few seconds ahead of us, that’s why we can see it, pass through it but they can’t see us. There’s no possibility of interaction.
DOCTOR: But if you remove that circuit the different realities would align themselves with each other! People would be able to cross between them.
SHEPHERD: After about five minutes, yes.
SCULLOP: You could step into the programme? Get this Phillipa of yours out?
DOCTOR: Theoretically.
SCULLOP: Then why don’t you do that?
DOCTOR: Because it’s a deeply irresponsible thing to do. We can’t risk anything created in that dimension getting out into this one!
SCULLOP: (BEAT) I see.
DOCTOR: But it does give me an idea. The bubble’s in a different time period, you say?
SHEPHERD: Two point six seconds ahead of us, I think it is.
SCULLOP: So?
DOCTOR: Time is a speciality of mine. If I create a fluctuating pulse within the security protocols, I should be able to make the two dimensions connect for the tiniest fraction of a moment on a recurring loop, once every second.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 60
SHEPHERD: Not enough for anything to pass from the fictional dimension to ours —
DOCTOR: But enough for me to slip through in my TARDIS, pick up Flip and get out again. With exceptional piloting skills, of course.
SHEPHERD: It could work. You can do that?
DOCTOR: I am very good.
SCULLOP: Then get on with it. The screening’s been disrupted enough already. In fact, I should be getting back there now. The actors will be restless, you know what they’re like...
DOCTOR: By all means.
SCULLOP: Doctor Shepherd, we shall speak later.
SHEPHERD: Thanks for that, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Oh, my pleasure.
SHEPHERD: Doctor...?
DOCTOR: Hmm?
SHEPHERD: You were worried about the Porcians. Who are they, what do they do?
DOCTOR: The Porcians? Invade planets, mostly.
SHEPHERD: What? And that’s what’s worrying you? An attempted take-over?
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 61
DOCTOR: What? Oh no, no. Not remotely. That’s not troubling me at all.
SHEPHERD: Then what?
DOCTOR: The problem isn’t them invading planets. The problem is that they’re not very good at it.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 62
WARMONGERS: Rongle-shonga. Shabbla-maspartan. Slibbly-doodell.
JANCEY: Why hasn’t he done something?
LASER: You know, I think I’ve had just about enough sitting here. I think it’s high time we escaped.
FLIP: What? How’d you plan on doing that?
LASER: Follow my lead.
KRARN: Gentleman and ladies. The hour of your execution is at hand.
LASER: Is it indeed? I think I know someone who might disagree with you.
KRARN: And who might that be?
LASER: Ask them. They’re standing right behind you.
KRARN: (TURNING) What?
LASER: You two, run!
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 63
FLIP: Can’t believe he fell for that...
LASER: For a world conquering dictator he really isn’t all that bright...
FLIP: And still the music!
LASER: Of course.
JANCEY: There’s always music at moments like this.
FLIP: Dramatic ones? This is beginning to make a crazy sort of sense
FLIP: Oh, crap, get off me!
FLIP: (LASER AND JANCEY SKID TO A HALT AS FLIP AND THE WARMONGER STRUGGLE)
LASER: It’s got you!
FLIP: Way ahead of you mate!
JANCEY: No! Let me go! (SCREAMS )
FLIP: Oh, would you not shut up!
JANCEY: Go, Jack! Save yourself!
FLIP: Who made you spokeswoman?
LASER: I’m not leaving you!
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 64
JANCEY: Go, get help! You can’t save us if you’re dead.
JANCEY: (LASER BLASTS FROM BEHIND. THE GROWL OF MORE ADVANCING WARMONGERS. BEAT)
LASER: I'll be back.
KRARN: There he goes. Fleeing like the coward he is. Kill him.
KRARN: (THE WARMONGERS SHOOT. A DEADLY BARRAGE OF FIREPOWER FOR AS
LONG: AS POSSIBLE. BEAT)
LONG: Missed.
FLIP: Yeah, from, like, ten yards! Not exactly crack shots, are
FLIP: they? They’re like terrorists trying to take out Bruce Willis.
KRARN: Are you criticising my Warmongers?
FLIP: Wanna make something of it?
KRARN: He will not have gone far. Bring the women. I think I have a means of persuading his return.
JANCEY: Why are you trying to anger him? He kills people for
JANCEY: breakfast, he’s insane!
FLIP: Trust me. I know what I’m doing.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 65
DOCTOR: Sonic probe.
SHEPHERD: There you go. (GIVES IT TO HIM) Three PHDs and I’m acting like a surgical nurse. (SIGHS) So. The Porcians try to conquer planets but they’re what? Not good at it?
DOCTOR: Notoriously so. They’re quite a joke in the galactic community. They invade worlds that are about to be destroyed in supernovae, worlds that are actually carnivorous, worlds that just happen to be called Skaro — or they take the wrong equipment, accidentally blow up their entire invasion fleet, get sucked into a black hole before they can arrive. Whatever it is, they always lose, though give them their dues, they’ve never made the same mistake twice.
SHEPHERD: So why do they do it?
DOCTOR: Have you never had ambitions you couldn’t fulfil? If you really desire them you keep trying, you persist. The Porcians see the spectacular achievements of the Daleks and the Cybermen and think they can manage the same. Unfortunately they don’t have the talent or ability to pull it off.
SHEPHERD: Oh my God. They’re wannabe alien invaders?
DOCTOR: That’s about the size of it, yes.
SHEPHERD: But if they’re so bad, what’s the problem? Surely rubbish alien invaders are better than good ones?
DOCTOR: Not for them. They’ve wiped out nearly their entire species with one hair-brained scheme for galactic domination or another. Whenever I’ve encountered them before I’ve taken all manner of risks to prevent their imminent extinction.
SHEPHERD: But surely that’s their problem, not ours.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 66
DOCTOR: Whatever they’re planning, and they are planning something, I can promise you that, whatever it is, they’ve messed it up. That’s what they do. And you don’t want to be within a million miles of one of their failures when it happens. They’re often more damaging than any possible success could be.
SHEPHERD: Collateral damage?
DOCTOR: Sometimes to the tune of whole planets.
SHEPHERD: I can see why you might be worried.
DOCTOR: We'll deal with them later. Take the communicator. Clear the screening room and let me know when it’s empty. I don’t want to risk anyone getting trapped between dimensions at an inopportune moment. Then I’1l set the pulse and head for the TARDIS.
SHEPHERD: On my way.
DOCTOR: (TO HIMSELF) Nearly there...
DOCTOR: (TURNING) Did you forget some(thing) — ?
CHIMBLY: Ah. Doctor. We meet again.
DOCTOR: (SIGHS) Not now.
CHIMBLY: Cover him.
JUNIOR: Sir.
DOCTOR: (BEAT) Alright, which one are you?
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 67
CHIMBLY: You don’t recognise me?
DOCTOR: I’ve met several of your species in my time. You’re walking pigs in silver bodystockings and cloaks — and whilst your generic appearance is undeniably distinctive, individually you are quite hard to tell apart.
CHIMBLY: You’re saying we all look the same? Bit racist.
DOCTOR: Well?
CHIMBLY: I am the Porcian known in our mother tongue as ‘Death Bringer, slayer of all, destroyer of Worlds’.
DOCTOR: Ah. Which in English is pronounced ‘Chimbly’.
CHIMBLY: I believe so.
DOCTOR: Yes, I suspect it loses some dramatic impact in translation. I remember you. Balastron Seven, wasn’t it?
CHIMBLY: Amongst others.
DOCTOR: Mister Chimbly —
CHIMBLY: Doctor! I don’t intend to waste any more time on you than I need to. Kill him.
JUNIOR: Sir.
DOCTOR: What? No!
CHIMBLY: Excellent. He is dead. (BEAT) You did remember to put it on the kill setting, didn’t you?
JUNIOR: Yes, sir.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 68
CHIMBLY: Only there was that time you had it on stun —
JUNIOR: It’s on kill, sir, look.
CHIMBLY: Oh. Yeah. Good. (BEAT) Excellent. He is dead. We may proceed.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 69
DOCTOR WHO: (KRARN OPERATES A CONTROL. HIS FIRST SPEECH IS SLIGHTLY AMPLIFIED)
KRARN: Listen to me, Laser, I know you can hear this. You must surrender immediately. If you do not return to your spacecraft within five minutes, I will execute the women you left behind. Starting with the one called Jancey.
FLIP: Who, if I remember rightly, didn’t tell you her name. So how d’you know it?
KRARN: What? Um...
JANCEY: Are you saying I’m a traitor?
FLIP: I’m saying it’s a continuity error. Hey mate, don’t start with her, start with me.
KRARN: You?
FLIP: Yeah, it’s dead boring hanging round here, let’s get it over with.
KRARN: You willingly embrace death?
FLIP: I don’t embrace nothing. You can stop it now. I know what’s going on.
KRARN: (BEMUSED) What’s going on?
FLIP: It’s pretty obvious. Dramatic music. Technobabble. The way you couldn’t hit the hero from point blank range?
JANCEY: I don’t —
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 70
FLIP: You’re fake! Fictional! What is this, a military re-enactment society? One of those immersive education centres?
KRARN: Do not try my patience, girl.
FLIP: Or what, you’ll shoot me? Come on, I’ve seen more realistic guns on Blue Peter. Go on. I dare you. I double dare you.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 71
SHEPHERD: Doctor? Doctor, are you there?
DOCTOR: (WAKING) What? Where am I?
SHEPHERD: Is that you?
DOCTOR: (TO HIMSELF) I thought they'd... but I seem to be fine... what happened there then?
SHEPHERD: Doctor, have you installed the pulse into the security protocols?
DOCTOR: (FINALLY COMING ROUND) Er... no, no. I was close but... the Porcians...
SHEPHERD: Then you need to get up here. I think something awful’s about to happen.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 72
KRARN: I have murdered millions of people on your world. You think I would hesitate to shoot you.
FLIP: Well, you haven’t yet, have you?
WARMONGERS: Robla-shalobla! Clamble peltula!
FLIP: Yeah, you lot can shut up too. I mean, it’s not like you’re really talking to each other. That’s why I can’t understand you. It’s not actually language. You’re just making up a load of gibberish and pretending it’s words.
JANCEY: You're making him angry!
FLIP: And it’s why you’re either screaming or talking like you’re reading the plot summary off Wikipedia.
KRARN: I need only one hostage.
FLIP: Give it a rest!
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 73
NICK: Wow. This is getting good. Tense.
MATTHEW: I don’t think I like where this is going...
DOCTOR: What is it? What’s the —
FLIP: I get it. You’re not real.
DOCTOR: No.
FLIP: You can stop pretending.
SHEPHERD: She thinks it’s safe.
KRARN: You don’t think my threat serious?
FLIP: Nah. I’m not soft.
DOCTOR: No, please Flip, he is real, he is for you, please, you’re in deadly danger.
FLIP: I mean, you’ve got no motivation. No-one kills people willy- nilly, for no reason.
KRARN: I do. And you are giving me plenty of reason now.
DOCTOR: Is there any way to communicate with her? Stop her before she does something stupid?
SHEPHERD: Not that I can see.
KRARN: I give you one last chance.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 74
FLIP: And that whole dead wife thing where you’ve clearly not figured out the details, I mean how clichéd was that —
DOCTOR: No!
FLIP: See, don’t feel a — (THE PAIN STARTS TO HIT) Actually that hurts quite a...
KRARN: You dare insult the memory of my wife? My beloved wife?
DOCTOR: She’s — He’s — There must be some way to stop this!
SHEPHERD: I’m sorry.
FLIP: (LOSING CONSCIOUSNESS, HALF DELIRIOUS) Is that... blood? That’s my blood.
KRARN: I should make you suffer. But I do not have the time to waste on vermin like you. So I shall put you out of my misery as quickly as I can. Kill shot to the head.
FLIP: (RAPIDLY, TEARFUL) No, please, I’m sorry, I made a mistake, I
DOCTOR: NO!
SHEPHERD: Oh, Doctor, I’m so sorry.
NICK: Wow! Those effects were magnificent, that looked practically real!
DOCTOR: He... killed Flip.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 75
KRARN: Thus die all who presume to mock the invincible evil of Lord Krarn!
SHEPHERD: I know.
DOCTOR: He shot her. I saw him shoot her.
SHEPHERD: I know.
DOCTOR: She's... dead.
DOCTOR: (THERE IS A STRANGE WOBBLE IN THE AIR. THE TWO DIMENSIONS
MERGE: )
SHEPHERD: What was that?
KRARN: What has happened? Who are you people?
SHEPHERD: Doctor...
KRARN: Where am I? You dare to kidnap the invincible Lord Krarn and his Warmongers?
MATTHEW: Erm... what’s going on?
SHEPHERD: The security protocols are down. They can hear us. They can see us.
KRARN: Answer me!
SHEPHERD: Doctor. They can leave the programme. They can leave the programme!
KRARN: I shall kill you all for this! I shall kill you all! WARMONGERS! DESTROY THEM!
DOCTOR WHO: THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 76

elements.text: PART THREE
THEME
37. (CONT) INT. SCREENING ROOM
Where am I? You dare to kidnap the invincible Lord Krarn and
his Warmongers?
Erm... what’s going on?
The security protocols are down. They can hear us. They can
see us.
Answer me!
Doctor. They can leave the programme. They can leave the
programme !
I shall kill you all for this! I shall kill you all! WARMONGERS! DESTROY THEM!
LASER BLASTS INTO THE AUDIENCE. DEATH AND SCREAMS
No!
GENERAL PANIC, OLIVIA AND OTHERS RUN FROM THE ROOM
No, you are not going anywhere! Kill them!
MORE BLASTS AND DEATH
Die for your arrogance!
MASS SCRAMBLE OUT UNDER THE REST OF THE SCENE
Doctor! Doctor, get down!
What? Oh, er, yes...
I’m so out of here!
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 77
SHE RUNS
No!
HE BLASTS AT HER, BUT SHE’S GONE
Ah! Both of Laser’s friends... gone! No matter. I have several new hostages I can kill!
LAUGHING MANIACALLY HE BLASTS INTO THE CROWD. SCREAMS, ETC.
Matthew, Matthew, what you doing, you insane?
That’s not me!
What? What, but — Who?
Laser!
Eh?
So this was your plan all along, was it?
Um, think you’re confusing me with someone else.
You believe I would mistake the visage of the man who slaughtered my beloved?
Ah, right, see what you’ve done there. Face is the same, yes, but...
Destroy him!
No!
BARRAGE OF GUNFIRE FOR A FEW SECONDS. BEAT
That could have killed me!
Am I to be surrounded by fools!
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 78
Oh, stuff this!
NICK SPRINTS FROM THE ROOM
Out the way! Get out the way! Talent coming through!
HE BARGES HIS WAY OUT
No! Come back! I will not lose you twice in one day! Come back so I may kill you! (PAUSE) After him! Destroy all who stand between us!
(THE WARMONGERS GRUNT, THEN BLAST THEIR WAY FROM THE ROOM,
SCREAMS AND DEATH FROM MISCELLANEOUS CAST AND CREW)

(TO ROOM IN GENERAL) The rest of you! Do not think you have escaped my fury. All will die. I swear it. (TO REMAINING WARMONGERS) Summon the rest of the Warmongers from the wilderness. I would have this place levelled to the ground!
HE LEAVES WITH THE OTHERS. BEHIND GENERAL DYING AND SOBBING
That was.. horrible, that was... me...
(AFTER A MOMENT, QUIETLY) Doctor? Doctor, I think they’ve gone.
(DISTRACTED) Yes.
Are you alright?
Am I alright? Am I alright! Flip’s dead. She’s dead! He shot her. He shot Flip.
I know. I saw.
He killed her without the slightest thought, the slightest compunction —
He’s insane. He’s a killer.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 79
I’m going into the programme. Maybe it was just an injury, a flesh wound —
You saw the blood Doctor, you saw what happened to her, no-one could survive that —
If there’s the slightest hope, the slightest chance, I have to save her.
There isn’t! Doctor, I know you’re upset, but you have to be realistic, there are more of those creatures in there... he’s summoned them!
I am not giving up, not yet. If you want to go you are more than welcome, but I will not abandon her!
BEAT
I’d better come with you.
Take my hand.
Okay. (DISGUSING NERVES) Funny, I’ve never been on telly before.
What?
Sorry, bad timing. I’m just a bit... nervous.
I understand. Here we go!
FAINT DISTORTION AS THEY STEP THROUGH
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 80
38. INT. PORCIAN’S SHIP
FLIGHT CONTROLS BEING ACTIVATED
Excellent. We have what we came for. We may leave.
We did well, sir.
What?
Er... we did well?
I know! That’s implicit in the whole ‘we’ve got what we came for’ bit. You don’t need to state the blinking obvious every time!
Erm...
Activate launch sequence.
Launch sequence activated.
(HE PRESSES A BUTTON. AN ALARM RINGS OUT FROM OUTSIDE THE SHIP)
I didn’t do nothing!
(THROUGH TANNOY) Attention vessel.
What the —
Unauthorised launch attempted.
Un-authorised?
Planetoid entering security lockdown. No departures allowed without personal key-code of Augustus Scullop.
Personal — what on — did you know about this?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney
No!
Please abandon your vessel!
Oh, swill.
THE ALARM BLARES
Page 81
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 82
39. INT. LASER’S SHIP
COMPUTERS TICKING OVER IDLY
This is.. strange... this close it looks fake, but it’s... it’s not. It works, it’s real. (BEAT) Is she — ?
No pulse. She’s gone.
I’m sorry.
She was so young. So young, only... (PAUSE) That’s amazing. You know, I’ve no idea how old she was. Human maturation’s hard to gauge at the best of times...
Human?
I was going to show her the universe. And I got her killed.
You couldn’t have known.
Couldn’t I? I’m not like you, Doctor Shepherd. I carry death with me everywhere I go. It was only a matter of time...
We have to go now...
There’s always a risk. I knew that. But I save them. I always save them. Why couldn’t I save her?
You can mourn her later. We’re on a fictional Earth surrounded by fictional killing machines that are coming to destroy us. We need to get out of here.
I’m not leaving her! Dead on the floor in a reality that isn’t
even her own?
She wouldn’t want you to join her, would she?
PAUSE
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 83
I’1l come back Flip. I’1l take you home.
The screening room. Let’s go.
THEY MOVE OFF
If we hurry we can make it to the docking bay and get off Transmission...
We’re not going anywhere.
What?
We have more important priorities.
Such as?
LEAPS OUT, SCREECHING.
DRAMATIC CHORD
Oh no.
Well, him for a start.
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 84
40. INT. CORRIDOR
(JANCEY RUNNING DOWN A CORRIDOR. DISTANT GUN BLASTING AND DEATH)
Way out... way out.. there’s got to be a way out somewhere —
SHE RUNS INTO OLIVIA
You?
No! They’ve made an evil android duplicate of me! I’1l be killed! (SHE SCREAMS)
No, no, no, calm down, calm down, I’m not here to kill you!
You are here to kill me! Why else would you have stolen my face! (MORE SCREAMS )
No, no, I’m really not!
What do you want, you monster?
I'm. I’m not a monster, I’m — oh, this is difficult...
You’re going to kill me and replace me and infiltrate the resistance movement in my place, aren’t you, that’s what you’re planning!
There is no resistance movement!
Keep back!
Okay, okay, look, please listen to me, just listen to me, I’m trying to get out of here too, like you, you understand, I just want to get out of here!
You... do?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 85
Yes, I —
GUN BLASTS — WARMONGERS ARE APPROACHING
Oh no!
It’s the Warmongers! (SCREAMS)
Right, no time to explain, follow me!
GRABS HER, DRAGS HER AWAY. THEY RUN
But... but you’re on their side!
I’m not.
You’re evil.
They’re shooting at me too, you stupid cow, we’re clearly not
friends!
Um...
This way. The docks, we can get off world... Run!
THE WARMONGERS CHASE THEM, FIRING
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 86
41. INT. LASER’S SHIP
GROWLING
Tell me, Doctor Shepherd, you know this reality better than I do, how do you defeat these creatures?
You can’t, they’re indestructible.
What?
Lasers, bullets, nuclear explosions, nothing stops them.
Nothing?
It was more dramatic that way.
THE WARMONGER LUNGES. THEY DART OUT OF ITS WAY
So first you unleash onto our galaxy a race of psychotically insane killing machines. Now you’re saying they’re impossible
to destroy for no better reason than because you say so?
I’m sorry...
MORE ROARING AND LUNGING
Perhaps if we draw it over here, we'll be able to double back
around it, get out into the screening room and then —
ARRIVING, ROARING
Doctor! There’s another one!
Ah. Well, never mind, it wasn’t a very good plan anyway.
DRAMATIC MUSIC
Hold on? What’s that music?
THE FOURTH WALL by John Dorney Page 87
